text:
Some time ago, there was a website that talked about the risks of public check-ins. It said that if you post something online, it can be seen by a lot of people. This made people think about the downsides of sharing their lives online. The website also talked about the benefits of sharing online, such as wealth and fame.
In the early days of the web, there were people who started posting their lives online. One of these people was Justin Hall. He started a blog and people from all over the world started reading it. Hall's blog was popular because he was very open and honest about his life. However, one day Hall's blog was taken down because someone sent the address of his blog to his boss. This made Hall feel bad, but it also made him realize that the web can be a dangerous place.
Heather Armstrong is another person who has experienced the risks of sharing online. She had a blog and one day an anonymous person sent the address of her blog to her boss. This resulted in her being fired from her job. Armstrong was upset, but she also learned from her experience. She realized that the web can be a dangerous place and that we should be careful about what we post online.

A long time ago, some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a movie called What the Bleep Do We Know. The movie showed that there is a lot about the universe that we don't understand. Some people felt that the movie was dangerous and issued warnings about it. The movie was very popular, but I couldn't see what all the fuss was about at first. However, when the movie moved on to describe some of the new discoveries, I began to see what the fuss was really about. One of the discoveries was that water molecules can be affected by thoughts. I had heard rumours about this before, but the movie gave me some evidence to support it. The evidence was not very convincing, but it was enough to make me believe that the discovery was real. The movie also talked about other discoveries, such as the expansion of the universe and the nature of reality. These discoveries were even more astounding than the discovery of water molecules being affected by thoughts. Despite what some people might believe, science shows no signs of reaching completion. We appear to be further away from omniscience than ever.

Writing novels is like planting a forest, while writing short stories is more like planting a garden. The two processes complement each other, creating a complete landscape. Writing novels takes a long time and requires a lot of commitment, while writing short stories is quicker and easier to complete. You can create a story out of the smallest things and experiment with different ideas. Short stories are like guideposts to your heart, and they can make you happy as a writer.

Science is a powerful force that has greatly impacted human life. It has improved our lives and presented challenges. It has also inspired artists and thinkers. Science has its beauty and its dangers. It has been used to heal diseases and to understand the universe. However, science is not perfect. It is constantly changing and evolving. Scientists come in many colors, and their work is often characterized by conflict. The history of science is filled with examples of scientific change. Sometimes, scientific theories are overthrown and replaced by new ones. This book presents science as a series of ideas that changed the course of human thought. Science has its practical benefits, but its primary concern is not to explain non-stick frying pans. It is to explore the unknown and to understand the universe. Science has become part of the human race’s way of conceiving of and manipulating its future.

From around 2015, major publishers started to report that sales of ebooks had plateaued or even fallen in some cases. This has raised concerns about the long-term potential of ebooks in the publishing industry. Some people believe that the ebooks hype may have driven unwise investment, with companies losing confidence in the power of the word on the page. Despite the evidence, the question of whether ebooks will 'kill' the print book still continues to surface.
The idea of one medium 'killing' another has often followed the unveiling of new technologies. Even before the advent of digital technologies, critics have predicted the demise of existing media. For example, when television was invented, many people thought that radio would die. But radio ended up surviving by finding new uses.
The emergence of new technology often causes us to adjust our bond with something that has become an integral part of our day-to-day life. As a result, as technology moves on, we find ourselves longing for what we used to know, but no longer have. This is why entire industries develop around retro products and older technologies.

Every day, I wake up early, brush my teeth, and make coffee. I write about how some of the greatest minds of the past have approached their work. I want to provide a new perspective on their personalities and careers. I also write about my own struggles with creativity and productivity.
I have a lot of concerns about creative work. How do you do meaningful creative work while also earning a living? Is it better to devote yourself wholly to a project or to set aside a small portion of each day? And when there doesn’t seem to be enough time for all you hope to accomplish, must you give things up or can you learn to condense activities, to do more in less time, to ‘work smarter, not harder’, as my dad is always telling me?
I have tried to provide examples of how a variety of brilliant and successful people have confronted similar challenges. I wanted to show how grand creative visions translate to small daily increments; how one’s working habits influence the work itself, and vice versa.
This book is about people’s routines. It’s about the circumstances of creative activity, not the product; it deals with manufacturing rather than meaning. But it’s also, inevitably, personal. I have documented all of my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will also serve as a guide to further reading.

Howard became a palaeontologist because he was inspired by a rise in interest rates when he was young. He found out that he wanted to become a palaeontologist when he was at university. He studied delicate creatures revealed on the surface of grey rocks. He got a job as a palaeontologist at a college in London. He often found himself contrasting the orderly nature of his professional life with the anarchy of private concerns.
One day, Howard's briefcase was stolen. He was fuming and returned to the college. He made an explanatory phone call and postponed the lecture. He reported the theft to the appropriate authorities and then went for a restorative coffee. He joined a colleague who was entertaining a visiting curator from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. And thus it was that Howard learned of the recently acquired collection of fossils, the study of which would provide him with his greatest challenge and ensure his professional future.

Charles Spence is a Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. He has studied how the senses interact to form our perception of flavour. Through his studies, he has influenced what we eat and drink. He has also studied how the environment affects taste.
Spence has written a book called The Perfect Meal, which is packed with insights that are fascinating to anyone in possession of an appetite. It includes information about how much we eat when eating with others and how music and sound can affect taste.
Spence's lab is un-space-age. It has soundproof booths and stacks of ancient-looking audio-visual equipment. He can afford to work more creatively with cooks because he keeps his overheads low.
Spence is currently helping famous brands through reductions in salt and sugar. He points out that it is in their interests to help loyal customers stay alive for longer.
What, one wonders, are dinner parties like in the Spence household? They're all extensions of the lab to Spence.

Our brains are very busy these days. We have a lot of information to deal with, including facts, rumors, and things that are not true. We also do more things ourselves now than we used to. For example, we make our own reservations and find things in shops. We do a lot of different things at once, but it turns out that this is not multitasking. Multitasking is a powerful and dangerous illusion. It actually makes us less efficient. It also increases the production of stress hormones and makes it harder to focus. If you are trying to focus on a task while there is an unread email in your inbox, your effective IQ can be reduced by almost 10 points. Multitasking also requires decision-making, which is also very hard on our brains. We rapidly spiral into a depleted state in which we can end up making truly bad decisions about something important.

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino would sometimes break up concrete into pieces and throw them at visitors. Was he being spiteful? In caves in the US, female bats help unrelated fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right birthing position. Are they being caring? Fifty years ago, people thought that animals didn’t have consciousness, feelings or moral systems. But recently that has partially changed. Thanks to research into the behaviour of bats, chimps, and other animals, emotions of animals have gone from being a taboo area of investigation to being tentatively explored. The new research has started a debate about whether animals can be said to have consciousness and conscience. If animals do have consciousness, what does it mean for the production and consumption of meat? The observations may not be disputed, but the interpretation of them is. Some people believe that we should stop eating meat, while others believe that we should at least re-evaluate our view of animal cognition. The debate is complex and there is no easy answer.

Critical thinking is a way of understanding what we read or listen to in a deeper way. It involves interacting with the text and thinking about the meaning of the words and ideas. There is a belief that argument is a way of finding the truth. Although technology can help us store and process information, it can also make it more difficult to think critically.
Reading enhances thinking and engages the imagination in a way that visual media such as video games and television do not. It develops imagination, induction, reflection, and critical thinking, as well as vocabulary. However, visual media can also improve some types of information processing.
Many people – particularly those who are younger – wind up underachieving and not making the most of their capabilities because of the way society views technology. It’s time to take a closer look at technology and understand the subtleties of how it affects thinking and analysis.

When Matthew Crawford is not writing or thinking about how we ought to live, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. He wrote two books about the benefits of manual trades and philosophy. One of his books is a quiet masterpiece about the benefits of the manual trades. The other book is a philosophical treatise on how to cope with modernity.
Crawford says that our attention is being pulled in many directions. We are being prevented from deciding what we want to be at the forefront of our mind. It is becoming more and more difficult to think or spend time remembering conversations we’ve had. And because everyone is trying to protect themselves from the irritation of constantly being interrupted, we close ourselves off and no longer want to do simple things like chat to strangers.
Crawford's proposed solution has two parts. First, we need regulation of noise and distraction in public space. More importantly, though, Crawford advocates skilled practices as a way of engaging with the world in a more satisfying way.

What do you do for a living? It's a common question that we use to define ourselves. As a philosopher, it's a little harder to deal with. One reason is that describing yourself as a philosopher sounds rather pretentious. Another reason is that philosophy has become increasingly removed from lived experiences. However, philosophy can also help people look a little more closely at the practices and behaviours that define their lives.

Foodies, gourmands, chefs and others who love food might expect that reflecting on what and how we eat can contribute to culinary pleasure. However, philosophical discussions of food have often been about other topics, such as the acquisition of knowledge or the pursuit of pleasure. Food is inherently social and cultural. It derives from historical contexts and is shared with those in our communities. It also brings people together and provides infrastructure for growing and distributing food. Ethical issues related to food include what we should eat and the extent to which cooking in restaurants and in the home differ. Cooking in the home is often more intimate and inclusive, while cooking for a living involves different obligations and restrictions. Food and dining can play a role in bridging cultural gaps. We can come to appreciate others by learning to enjoy their food and forge personal bonds with people from other cultures by coming together to eat.

Rob Daviau is a US-based game designer who creates legacy board games. These games are different from traditional board games because they have a permanent impact on the game. For example, in one game, players might have to rip up cards, deface the board, or open packets containing new rules. The games play out over a fixed number of sessions and long-held grudges become woven into the fabric of the game.
Legacy board games were not expected to go mainstream, but most players love the concept. They see it as one of the biggest advances in game design for several years. The appeal of an unfolding adventure trumped any concerns about longevity.
The legacy format draws on video games and the demand for episodic entertainment fuelled by popular TV series. Daviau feels a sense of ownership, but he is keen to see where others take the idea.

Once upon a time, there was an octopus named Inky who lived in New Zealand. One night, Inky managed to escape from his tank and swim across the floor to a drain that led to the ocean. It was a story that was shared online and was popular. One of the reasons why people enjoyed the story was because it was about anthropomorphism, which is like treating animals like humans. Dr. Frans de Waal is a scientist who studies primates and he believes that anthropomorphism is not accurate. He says that animals have many of the same abilities as humans, such as the ability to think about the past and the future, to demonstrate empathy, and to be self-aware. De Waal also points out that humans have a lot of negative habits, such as destroying animal habitats and polluting the environment. But he believes that we are starting to learn to appreciate animal intelligence and that we can all learn from animals.

Once upon a time, there was a technology called robotics that has the potential to change the world. Robots have already been used in the automotive and manufacturing industries for many years. Experts say that in the next few years, robots will be used in many other industries. This technology will definitely impact lower-skilled people, but it also presents an opportunity for companies to grow and create new jobs.
In order to prepare for the future, we need to invest in education and training programs. We also need to develop new regulatory frameworks to ensure our safety and privacy. With millions of jobs at risk and a worldwide employment crisis looming, it is only logical that we should turn to education to understand and prepare for the robotic workforce of tomorrow.

Because it's there, the mountaineer George Mallory is said to have said when asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest. People have a desire to understand why anyone would participate in such a seemingly meaningless and life-threatening pursuit. Climbing can be a very confining and restricting activity, yet it can also give a feeling of freedom. There is an apparent paradox in many forms of climbing. Climbing can help cultivate important virtues such as courage, humility and respect for the environment. One further belief worth exploring is that climbers who do not rely on other people or technology to help them, have to be totally committed to their goal in order to succeed.

Alfred Brendel is a famous pianist who has been playing classical music for many years. He is known for his intellectual and disciplined personality. Brendel has written and played a lot of music, but he has not taught very much. Those who knew him best saw a playful side to his character, but that was seldom on display in his concerts.
Brendel has a young student named Kit Armstrong. Kit is a restless and impatient young man who is always learning new things. He is also a gifted composer. Brendel has noticed that Kit has a phenomenal memory and that he is a phenomenal sight reader. He also says that Kit has a great ability to listen to his own playing and to understand what Brendel is saying.
Brendel is proud of Kit and he is excited about his future. He knows that Kit has the potential to be a great pianist. However, he also knows that it is important to be patient and to not expect too much from young players.

My grandparents' garden was a beautiful place. It was on the bank of a river and sloped gently down towards the water. You couldn’t reach the river but you could hear the sound of the water and the birds that sang in the trees above. I imagined that all gardens were like this – a place of escape, peace and solitude.
My father was a quiet and withdrawn person. He had a lot of phrases that he liked to use, one of them being 'It’s immaterial to me'. He was probably disappointed that he hadn’t made more of his life. He left school without qualifications and became apprenticed to a plumber. It was not something he was passionate about.
I always wanted to like the piano but it did its best to intimidate me. The only thing I did like about it were the two brass candlesticks that jutted out from the front. I would often spend time imagining myself playing the piano, but I never had the opportunity to learn.
I wanted out of school as soon as possible. One day my father announced, 'They’ve got a vacancy for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.' In one brief moment Dad had gone against his better judgement. He might still have preferred it if I became a carpenter. But I like to feel that somewhere deep down inside him was a feeling that things might just turn out for the best. If I stuck at it.

Lawrence MacEwen lives on the Isle of Muck, a small island in Scotland. The island is surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean. There is a strong wind blowing, and the waves are high. MacEwen's sheepdog, Tie, is playing with the sheep. The wind is very strong, but MacEwen is not worried. He is happy on his island. MacEwen is giving me a tour of his neighbourhood. He tells me about the different islands and the weather. He also tells me about his family and their farm. The island life is not perfect, but MacEwen is still happy. He has a good life, and he is grateful for the things he has.

The game design industry was once a niche hobby, but it has become a serious industry. It is not easy to get into, but it is expanding. To get into the industry, you need to make games. You can do it on your own, but it is pretty tricky. A good postgraduate course in games can help, plus provide a year or two of top-level support and guidance. If you are interested in games, you should have a healthy appetite for all areas of the arts and contemporary culture. And finally, connections can help.
The game design industry is growing rapidly. It is becoming more pervasive and accessible to a wider audience. Families frequently get involved on interactive consoles. Smart phones introduce a wealth of new games through apps, as well as social media. There is plenty of room for expansion in the games industry.

Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, and I'm grateful that he didn't push me too hard. I had a friend who was also passionate about football, but he stopped playing and hasn't been involved in the sport since. I'm glad that I didn't have that happen to me. I have worked hard to improve my skills, and I know that with practice, anyone can achieve great things.
I also used to play other sports at school, but football was my favorite. I want to make sure that my son has the same opportunities that I had, so I'm trying to read him books even though he's far too young to sit still for long enough. I hope that he doesn't take after me in that way.
I have a lot of money, but I don't have all the answers. After I've stopped playing, I think I'll have a year off or perhaps even longer, doing the things I haven't been able to do all these years. I want to go skiing the day after I stop playing, but I can't do that now because if I were to break a leg on the ski slopes and couldn't play football again, I wouldn't be insured.

It was because of Sam Carter that we were living at Reef Point. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He offered to find somewhere cheap for us to live. The beach had been deserted since the warm weather had been blanketed by sea fogs. Reef Point was seldom patronised by the casual day tripper. There were a few things that I had to return to their anxious owners. I liked to swim too, and always insisted on accompanying me, although I could swim much faster and farther than he could. One surfer in particular caught my eye. She had a style that made all the others look like clumsy amateurs.

Violet Hetherington was standing in a queue at the dock in Southampton. The queues were long and there was a lot of waiting passengers. There had been a problem with the computer system and the atmosphere became dark. Some people were patient, but most people were unhappy. Violet felt that the whole idea of the cruise was a mistake. She was also annoyed by the loss of her phone. She couldn’t call anyone because her numbers were stored in her phone. She was going to be in trouble because she had no other means of finding numbers she needed in New York. But she was thankful that she had a balcony in her room. She had been anxiously rehearsing what to say if it had not.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he discovered the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maier was a street photographer with a keen eye for capturing compelling images. Maloof has amassed an archive of Maier’s life and work, which includes her cameras, film, prints, negatives, movies, and audiotapes.
Maier was born in 1926 and spent much of her childhood in France. She returned to New York in 1951 and came to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person but had a strong passion for photography. She always had a camera with her and dressed in oversized coats, broad-brimmed hats, and stout shoes.
Maier’s work is the purest form of art. None of it was done for any commercial reason. Her images lean toward women, children, the old, the poor, and the abstract. Maloof often wonders if he’ll ever work his way through all the negatives. Inspired by Maier’s architectural shots, Maloof actually went out on the street and began to take his own pictures.

When a novel is described as ambitious, it often suggests that it might not be successful. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. The book is set during the 1860s in New Zealand. A series of crimes have been committed, and a council of 12 men has convened to solve them. The plot is complex and exciting. Catton said she set out to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found the past offered more opportunities for complications and misunderstandings for her characters to deal with. The book is long, but Catton said she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters ‘a decent show’. Despite the experimental structure of The Luminaries, the book remains an exciting murder mystery with an absorbing plot.

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead loved to play the guitar. He learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven and wanted to learn the bass guitar when he was sixteen. He studied guitars and figured out how different shapes and types of wood affected the sound. He also learned how to build his own instruments.
Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, but he didn’t think of it as a career. He was also into painting and sculpture. He chose to study architecture at university but dropped out because he was too individualistic. He then realized that guitar-building is actually a type of sculpture and decided to make guitars for a living.
For the first ten years, Jonny supplemented his income by cleaning windows part-time. As he developed a reputation as one of the best guitar-makers around, he was able to charge a little more. But even now, almost forty years later, he describes what he does as ‘still scratching a living’.
Jonny believes developing a career is more straightforward for today’s new guitar-makers in the UK. He thinks new instrument-makers should do the courses on offer and learn from their mistakes.

Any conversation about English conversation often begins with the weather. It is a traditional way to start a conversation in English. The writer Dr. Johnson said that "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This observation is still accurate today. However, most people who write about the English "obsession" with the weather make a mistake. They assume that our conversations about the weather are actually about the weather. This is not true. Our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather at all. They are a form of "grooming talk."
There are certain fixed contexts in which weather-speak is used. It can be used as a simple greeting, as an ice-breaker leading to conversation on other matters, or as a "default" or "filler" topic when conversation on other matters dries up.

Alice Leader was standing in front of the remains of a Roman wall in Britain. She was explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an extraordinary feat of engineering it was. The wall was built 120 km long and 5 metres high. Alice felt her answers were unsatisfactory. She wrote her first novel to add context and human interest to life at the Wall in Roman times. After retiring from teaching, Alice embarked on a second career as an author. She wrote her first novel in 2001. She was inspired to write because there was a gap in the market for children's fiction. Her novel is about a Roman couple and their baby-to-be. Alice's husband is a critic and editor. He helped her edit her novel.

To raise money for charity, two brothers, Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, were challenged to take part in a unique race. The race would set man against car and brother against brother. It took place in the wild and mountainous Yorkshire Dales of northern England.
Jonny raced in a car on the roads, while Ali raced across the country on a mountain bike. The race started at a beautiful lake and finished at Yorkshire’s highest road.
There were some obstacles during the race. The first obstacle was a giant tractor that lumbered out of a field and onto the road. The second obstacle was the slope of the hill that forced Alistair to dismount and carry his bike up the hill.
In the end, Alistair won the race. He was very happy to have won.
